1113471622596517888.text: 20/ You can learn more about the project and team at http://celo.org . And Celo is actively hiring!

1113471621807919104.text: 19/ Please also see important information athttps://a16zcrypto.com/disclosures

1113471621011058688.text: 18/ The team has already made impressive progress towards launching the network later this year. We go into more depth why we’re passionate about this team in our blog post with @katie_haun.https://a16zcrypto.com/2019/04/celo/

1113471619824082945.text: 17/ You may think—this is a bold vision and lots of work for one team. We strongly believe that Celo is one of the strongest teams in the space, and is up to the task, with experienced engineers, designers, legal and policy experts, and researchers leading the effort.

1113471618850934784.text: 16/ Celo takes the best of the full stack experience, while still exposing a decentralized smart contract platform for developers to innovate on, without platform risk and within the full ethos of the crypto movement.

1113471618007932928.text: 15/ While Apple’s full stack ethos produced a completely integrated experiences, with hardware and software in harmony, it often went too far in usurping control, creating walled gardens, or worse yet, completely closed systems.

1113471617143836673.text: 14/ Celo integrates all this into a native a mobile SDK and best in class wallet, and surfaces a great developer and user experience to consumers as a result.

1113471615956914176.text: 13/ Celo has also introduced novel improvements with its consensus and proof innovations, making block validation on mobile devices efficient even on cheap Android phones with spotty service.

1113471615336091649.text: 12/ True mobile support for blockchains has left a lot to be desired, since mobile devices cannot serve as independent light clients because of their bandwidth and computational limitations.

1113471614333726720.text: 11/ Take volatility. I believe volatility is as user experience problem that developers are responsible for. Who wants to interact with an application via a currency that may lose 50% of value the next day? Celo integrates a stablecoin natively into its network.

1113471613603913729.text: 10/ In the Apple tradition, Celo is taking a full-stack approach, taking the best parts of crypto and improving on them to provide a fully-considered UX at the application layer.

1113471612739829762.text: 9/ It won’t be surprising if dominant blockchain architectures of the future, built with a consideration for UX, are fundamentally different from what we have today.

1113471611611619328.text: 8/ Instead of an app that “just works”, there is a need for extra tools, extra steps, and extra time. Users accustomed to a normal web experience find it unusable. Try giving a demo of your favorite crypto app to an uninitiated friend. Mobile support is even worse.

1113471610961518592.text: 7/ In crypto today, different layers of an application’s experience are built by different teams, leading to a disjointed experience.

1113471610084892672.text: 6/ While many improvements are in the works around the space, they look more like a patchwork of fixes instead of an ideal architecture considered from first principles.

1113471609367613445.text: 5/ In the crypto world, fundamental architecture decisions at the blockchain base impact the ergonomics of application developers. Complexity and friction at Layer 1 propagate all the way to the end-user.

1113471608751108097.text: 4/ It’s easy to take the base layer as a given and assume it is outside of the application developer’s control, but designing for harmony between hardware and software creates the ultimate end-user experience.

1113471607618572288.text: 3/ Apple’s realized the possibilities, limitations, and ergonomics of underlying hardware couple tightly with how we build software, and ultimately, the entire user experience.

1113471606972719105.text:
2/ Kay’s aphorism is one of Apple’s core principles. It was religiously cited by Steve Jobs.

Apple’s full-stack approach distinguished it from competitors and resulted in products that pulled the future forward and changed the world:

1008908095513219072.text: 14/ So don’t build walls between ideas—release and publish them early, and often!

1008908092904370178.text: 13/ Closed environments make it difficult to explore the “adjacent possible”.

1008908090178072576.text: 12/ Innovation does best when ideas can serendipitously connect and recombine with other ideas.

1008908087485321216.text: 11/ Most importantly, the free flow of ideas is crucial to a healthy and dynamic “adjacent possible”.

1008908083936890882.text: 10/ More big new ideas result from combining old ideas than from eureka moments.

1008908079927214080.text: 9/ Evolution is a tinkerer, not an engineer.

1008908059089907713.text: 8/ Carl Sagan describes the same process, in reverse.pic.twitter.com/9L7iCPXlOR

1008908025665470464.text:
7/ An invention is like a series of doors.

Every door leads to more doors—combinatorial possibilities of new ideas—you have to pick one and step through to see.

1008908022305837056.text:
6/ The “adjacent possible” captures both the limits and the creative potential of change and innovation.

Complex evolution will require multiple iterations—intermediate inventions—of adjacent possiblities.

1008908019126550528.text:
5/ You can create formaldehyde—a first-order combination in this iteration of the “adjacent possible”—directly from molecules in the primordial soup.

But you cannot create a sunflower. It relies on many subsequent innovations: chloroplasts, vascular tissues, DNA molecules.

1008908014793789440.text: 4/ Combining these molecules gives us most of the building blocks of life.

1008908011870420993.text: 3/ Before life emerged on Earth, the planet was dominated by a handful of basic molecules: ammonia, methane, water, carbon dioxide, a few amino acids and other simple organic compounds.

1008908004316442624.text: 2/ The adjacent possible is “a shadow of the future, hovering at the edge of the present.”

1008907992937320448.text:
1/ “The adjacent possible”

A map of the ways you can reinvent the present by taking existing ideas and recombining them into new forms.

Realizing a new possibility unlocks further combinations of ideas—therefore new innovations—ad infinitum.

1006627121383596033.text: 15/ Open discourse, open source, and market forces are force multipliers of the process.

1006627119630311429.text: 14/ Ultimately though, all projects in the space contribute to evolution and natural selection of crypto: most individual projects will die, but each experiment improves and strengthens crypto as a whole.

1006627118590189568.text: 13/ The same basic tenants underly the Lean Startup philosophy and the idea of a Minimum Viable Product.

1006627116979548160.text: 12/ Achieving absolute perfection may be impossible, and increasing effort results in diminishing returns.

1006627115331178496.text: 11/ The Pareto principle: it takes 20% of the effort to complete 80% of the task, while it takes 80% of effort complete the remaining 20%.

1006627114228113408.text: 10/ Closely related: the aphorism “perfect is the enemy of good”, one may never complete a task if one decides not to stop until its prefect.

1006627112634191874.text: 9/ “The MIT guy then muttered that sometimes it takes a tough man to make a tender chicken, but the New Jersey guy didn’t understand”

1006627110277013504.text: 8/ “The New Jersey guy said that the Unix solution was right because the design philosophy of Unix was simplicity and that the right thing was too complex.”

1006627108230135811.text: 7/ He comically caricatured the two schools of thought the New Jersey approach and the MIT/Stanford style of design.

1006627106204286976.text: 6/ “Worse is Better” was originally coined by LISPer Richard Gabriel, on why C and UNIX ended up being better than LISP, even though LISP was “the-right-thing”.  http://www.dreamsongs.com/RiseOfWorseIsBetter.html …

1006627104895782914.text: 5/ Is mindshare more important than “the right thing”? Are competing projects simply testbeds for improvements to Ethereum?

1006627103264133126.text: 4/ Ethereum is half-baked, but the virus continues to spread: community is immense, dozens of talented and dedicated teams working on different kinds of scaling solutions.

1006627101045329922.text: 3/ Systems that want nearly 100% of functionality take a long time to implement and are large/complex.

1006627099413811204.text: 2/ Through this framework, Ethereum has better survival characteristics than “the-right-thing” solutions of gen-3 blockchains that promise to “fix all the things”.

1006627096976912385.text:

- half-baked solution (50% functionality)
- spreads like a virus
- evolves/improves after it is deployed

- “the right thing” upfront
- takes a long time to get to market
